title: Gear
body:
The gear plugins generates an error in the head of the teeth, an error that is accentuated if the number of teeth is increased.
![Uploading E09F813A-D59C-42C7-B5A1-EB93A130FF56.jpeg…]()

title: 4-axis and 5-axis support is broken (3 and 6 works)
body:
Previously I had bCNC-0.9.14.304 running and connecting to COM port (Tibbo virtual serial port) and arduino Mega.
I am using an Arduino mega board with wifi built in (ESP8266 on board).
I am using grbl fork for MEGA from:
https://github.com/LETARTARE/grblQ-Mega-4axes
I have installed the latest version of bCNC and tried both installing with python 2.7 & 3.
Both installs connect to a std COM, but not to the arduino Mega via usb or wifi. I have 2 arduino megas that I have tested with no luck.
I would love to get this working with my 4 axis cnc.  Im using windows 10.
Please advise.

Below is what i can find in the python terminal:

COM1    Communications Port (COM1)      ACPI\PNP0501\1

title: floating point exception
body:
Building a clean system on a VirtualBox VM using Debian and Python 2.7,  bCNC terminates immediately with a floating point exception. I do not see the usual python trace.
Here is what I did:
Installed Debian 10 on VirtualBox 
Enter "python", result is 2,7,16
Enter "python3", result is 3.7.3
The app sudo was installed already
added myself to sudoers 
installed pip using sudo apt install python-pip
added tkinter with sudo apt-get install python-tk
installed bCNC with pip install bCNC
added to path: /home/joe/.local/bin
Start bCNC with python -m bCNC;; got the following 2 lines:
self.canvas.winfo id(): 23068762
floating point exception

title: bCNC freezes on pocket action
body:
Hi,

after clicking the Pocket button twice bCNC freezes with this error:

```
self.canvas.winfo_id(): 100663381
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/bCNC/Utils.py", line 464, in __call__
    return self.func(*args)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/bCNC/ToolsPage.py", line 1747, in execute
    self.tools.getActive().execute(self.app)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/bCNC/ToolsPage.py", line 909, in execute
    app.pocket(name)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/bCNC/__main__.py", line 1827, in pocket
    msg = self.gcode.pocket(blocks, diameter, stepover, name)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/bCNC/CNC.py", line 4011, in pocket
    newpath.extend(self._pocket(path, -D*diameter, stepover, 0))
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable
```
steps to reproduce:
1. select object
2. click Pocket -> everything ok, showing the path
3. click Pocket again -> freeze :-(

I found out, that this seems to be happen when no object is selected

title: Problem with very very small values
body:
If the value is close to zero, it may be that the result obtained leads us to a wrong location, for example:
x 7.9335 e-06, the machine will go to x-7.9335 instead of zero.
It would be good a general solution to serve for all cases and plugins

title: USER Buttons saved where?
body:
After spending quite a bit of time writing a+-20 lines script/macro, and after closing/reopening bCNC, I saw the macro was not there anymore. The name was still there, but no text.
On 2 other buttons, it all went away, name and text!

So, where does bCNC save this, so that I could eventually get it back? (I am afraid to close bCNC, now....)

title: AttributeError: DROFrame instance has no attribute 'wcsSet' using Set WPOS
body:
Hi, I've updated the bCNC (0.9.14-dev) on my ubuntu 18.04 but now Set WPOS seems do not work, if I click it bCNC freeze and the only solution is to kill it.
The console write message "AttributeError: DROFrame instance has no attribute 'wcsSet'".

title: Memory access fault on Raspi
body:
(Debian Stretch, updated to current on Raspi 2)

After a longer hiatus I wanted to start up bCNC again. It didn't work so I updated with
'pip2 install --upgrade bCNC' as root.
This worked (after i had 'libjpeg-dev' installed).

Then as user:
markus@fraese:~$ python2 -m bCNC
new-config Utils <ConfigParser instance at 0x75e97e90>
Speicherzugriffsfehler
markus@fraese:~$ 

 Speicherzugriffsfehler = memory access fault

? what did I do wrong?

Thanks

title: Doing "cut" on simple non-closed path will close the path on the bottoming pass
body:
Doing a simple cut of a non-closed path from an SVG:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/395016/55048229-b0ee2880-5004-11e9-9be2-e0033833c528.png)

Gives unexpected results in Camotics -- essentially the path is inadvertently closed just before the final bottoming pass:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/395016/55048397-425d9a80-5005-11e9-9f5e-04e44f77983d.png)

Looking at [CNC.py:3532](https://github.com/vlachoudis/bCNC/blob/master/bCNC/CNC.py#L3532): `if splitpass: path.invert() #Fixes split ramp case`, commenting out this line fixes the issue.  

I _think_ that since `path.invert()` is called at [line 3515](https://github.com/vlachoudis/bCNC/blob/master/bCNC/CNC.py#L3515) _and_ [line 3518](https://github.com/vlachoudis/bCNC/blob/master/bCNC/CNC.py#L3518) before entering the bottoming block, then this final `path.invert()` shouldn't be necessary, but I'm not entirely sure.

title: Drag Knife post processor not working with some toolpaths
body:
The drag Knife post processor throws a math domain error with one of my gCode files. But if I enclose...

`angle = degrees(acos(TA.dot(TB)))`

in a `try: except` block, thus...

```
try:
    angle = degrees(acos(TA.dot(TB)))
except:
    continue
```

... the problem goes away. I have absolutely no idea what is going on with this toolpath so the above solution is probably a bit 'hacky'. Anyway, here is the problematic file:

[yrOrsaf3.ngc.zip](https://github.com/vlachoudis/bCNC/files/2999939/yrOrsaf3.ngc.zip)

title: TypeError: comports() takes no arguments (1 given)
body:
File "/mnt/vg3.2/home/smooker/src/bCNC/bCNC/FilePage.py", line 333, in comportRefresh
    for i in comports(include_links=True):
TypeError: comports() takes no arguments (1 given)



```
diff --git a/bCNC/FilePage.py b/bCNC/FilePage.py
index 3b0a241..3c1a8d5 100644
--- a/bCNC/FilePage.py
+++ b/bCNC/FilePage.py
@@ -330,7 +330,7 @@ class SerialFrame(CNCRibbon.PageLabelFrame):
        def comportRefresh(self, dbg=False):
                #Detect devices
                hwgrep = []
-               for i in comports(include_links=True):
+               for i in comports():
                        if dbg:
                                #Print list to console if requested
                                comport = ''
@@ -340,11 +340,11 @@ class SerialFrame(CNCRibbon.PageLabelFrame):
                                hwgrep += ["hwgrep://"+hw+"\t"+i[1]]
 
                #Populate combobox
-               devices = sorted([x[0]+"\t"+x[1] for x in comports(include_links=True)])
+               devices = sorted([x[0]+"\t"+x[1] for x in comports()])
                devices += ['']
                devices += sorted(set(hwgrep))
                devices += ['']
-               devices += sorted(["spy://"+x[0]+"?raw"+"\t(Debug) "+x[1] for x in comports(include_links=True)])
+               devices += sorted(["spy://"+x[0]+"?raw"+"\t(Debug) "+x[1] for x in comports()])
                devices += ['', 'socket://localhost:23', 'rfc2217://localhost:2217']
 
                #Clean neighbour duplicates

```

title: PIP installed bCNC seems unstable
body:
Hi 
I tried the bCNC Version installed with PIP (installed today - newest version).
I worked with it for an hour and bCNC crashed 3 times in 3 different ways!!
Everytime, there is a message to give a notice to the developer. So i did!

Luckily i had a second version of bCNC (an old one, not installed with PIP) and this one worked fine for hours. The same files, the same machine, twice as long and no Problems!!

body: Header/Footer not added to new file?

title: B-cnc stops sending data

labels.name: research and code cleanup
labels.description: long term ideas which need some more thinking

title: Milling with smoothieware results in command submission stopping after a while
body:
Scenario:

Proxxon MF70 with a Smoothieboard running Smoothieware, using firmware-cnc-latest (currently latest available, uploaded 9 days ago)

I am running the latest code installed with pip from git on Fedora (0.9.14, 5 Feb 2018)


1. I connect (serial port, SMOOTHIE)
2. Home
3. Load a gcode file generated in Fusion 360
4. Run

Result:

A few moves get executed, until everything just stops. The endstops aren't being hit, there's no alarms or errors displayed. 

The status says: Current 183 [3656] 
Controller buffer fill is at 93%

The status is "Idle"
The "Start" button remains greyed out.

On the terminal where I ran the program it says:

```
new-config Utils <ConfigParser.ConfigParser instance at 0x7f7aad9435f0>
Exception in thread Thread-2:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/threading.py", line 804, in __bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/threading.py", line 757, in run
    self.__target(*self.__args, **self.__kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/bCNC/Sender.py", line 738, in serialIO
    elif self.mcontrol.parseLine(line, cline, sline):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/bCNC/controllers/_GenericController.py", line 184, in parseLine
    self.parseBracketAngle(line, cline)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/bCNC/controllers/SMOOTHIE.py", line 53, in parseBracketAngle
    d= { a: [float(y) for y in b.split(',')] for a, b in [x.split(':') for x in l[1:]] }
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/bCNC/controllers/SMOOTHIE.py", line 53, in <dictcomp>
    d= { a: [float(y) for y in b.split(',')] for a, b in [x.split(':') for x in l[1:]] }
ValueError: invalid literal for float(): 40.010.

Will clean after this operation

```

The gcode file doesn't contain any '40.010' anywhere.

Further command submission fails. For instance I can't send an M999 to Smoothie.

So, suspecting that there's something wrong in the smoothie code, I tried connecting in GRBL1 mode. That actually worked better. The machine completed the ellipse this time, and went a tiny bit further:

Here's the end of the gcode window:

```
G18G2X32.051Z-0.7K0.3
ok
G1Z15F1000
ok
G17
ok
M5
ok
G28G91Z0
ok
G90
ok
M0
ok
T1
ok
S20000M3
ok
M106
ok
G0X5.225Y5.533F1000
ok
G0Z15
ok
G1Z5
ok
G1Z2.6F50
ok
```

Here's the buffer:

```
G1X5.25Y5.546Z2.53F300
G1X5.307Y5.583Z2.5
G3X4.729Y6.337Z2.448I-0.289J0.377
G3X5.307Y5.583Z2.396I0.289J-0.377
```

The terminal contains:

```
python2 -m bCNC
new-config Utils <ConfigParser.ConfigParser instance at 0x7fb7252865f0>
Controller state changed to: Alarm (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Home (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: False)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: False)
Will clean after this operation
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: True)
Controller state changed to: Run (Running: True)
Controller state changed to: Idle (Running: True)
Controller state changed to: Hold (Running: True)

```
A bunch of those is probably me jogging things around. The hold is also mine, but was issued only after the machine had stopped moving for quite some time.

I had inserted a manual tool change with Fusion 360, and wasn't sure what was going to happen at that point (I'm still very new to this), so there may be going something wrong with that. The status simply goes to "Idle", there's no message from the program of any sort.

Also, earlier I tried using Pronterface to submit gcode instead. That seemed to work perfectly fine, but it doesn't seem like the best fitting tool for the task.


Here's the gcode I'm sending:

[Vika.zip](https://github.com/vlachoudis/bCNC/files/2661018/Vika.zip)


So it seems there may be several issues here:

1. Smoothie support has some sort of bug in it
2. There are conditions in which bCNC can stop working and not say anything to the user
3. There may be an issue with different implementations of a manual tool change. It looks like Fusion 360's approach is an M0 rather than an M6.


Thanks!

title: Changing toolchange/probe MPos requires bCNC restart
body:
If i set toolchange and probe location, it does not apply until i restart the bCNC.
This can easily lead to crash.

title: Tool change commands not being sent
body:
Using 0.9.14 from today’s Git. When I try to send M6 commands (using the manual tool change option), nothing happens. Even manually entering M6 T1 nothing happens. I tried to change the setting to ignore, close, then reopen bCNC, still nothing.
Tks

title: bCNC as module creates two instances of config parser

labels.name: research and code cleanup
labels.description: long term ideas which need some more thinking

body:
Continuing from #964 

I think i am onto something. I've added following debug message to `Utils.py`:

```python
config    = ConfigParser.ConfigParser()
print "new-config", __name__, config 
```

When i run the bCNC as module, it creates two instances of config parser:

```
[harvie@anemophobia bCNC]$ python2 -m bCNC
new-config bCNC.Utils <ConfigParser.ConfigParser instance at 0x7fcca1177908>
new-config Utils <ConfigParser.ConfigParser instance at 0x7fcca0f94368>
```

When i run it directly it only creates single instance of that config parser:

```
[harvie@anemophobia bCNC]$ ./bCNC/bCNC
new-config Utils <ConfigParser.ConfigParser instance at 0x7faf2b9447e8>
```

That's because of multiple imports under different `__name__`. Once as `bCNC.Utils` and once as `Utils`. I have no idea how to fix this. The config file code seems to be complete mess as it uses global variable shared across whole project.

Thank you in advance
Greets Chris

_Originally posted by @einencool in https://github.com/vlachoudis/bCNC/issues/885#issuecomment-435475329_

title: G91 problems when moving or otherwise modifying
body:
When having block like this utilizing G91 it will fall apart when moved:

```gcode
(Block-name: block)
(Block-expand: 1)
(Block-enable: 1)
g0 x0 y0
g1 z0
g1 x10 y0
g91
g1 x0 y10
g1 x-10 y0
g90
g1 x0 y0
g0 z10
```

This is kinda fun, because you can make blocks that will change shapes when moved. However it's not really practical for CNC use:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/276504/42476801-5ae7fad0-83cf-11e8-848b-e18323f3fc29.png)

This is due to the fact that coordinates between G91 and G90 are translated too. bCNC should stop modifying coordinates after G91 and resume after G90 when moving block.

I am not really sure if this bug also affects other operations.

BTW Fixing this might make hand editing of tabs even more user friendly, since it will be needed to edit only 1 segment instead of 4 if we'll use G91 to describe tabs.

title: Can't properly detect path direction
body:
I made separate issue from this, as this affects multiple other issues: Namely #881 and #840 

Here you can clearly see that in some cases it gives oposite direction (see segment direction vs. overal path direction):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/276504/42172240-bc190498-7e1b-11e8-8251-63c095eef917.png)

When it fails to properly detect path direction i cannot properly implement conventional/climb milling. Also when i try to do pocket operation on such wrongly identified rectangle with overcuts it crashes on ifinite recursion OR shows this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/276504/42172073-3ea9c024-7e1b-11e8-9ada-be675adcfa0e.png)

title: Climb vs Conventional milling is other way round in bCNC! Defaults probably not sane.
body:
Right now it's:

Conventional = Always CCW
Climb = Always CW

bCNC has got this wrong. It should be like this:

Conventional = CW for inside profiles and pockets, CCW for outside profiles
Climb = CCW for inside profiles and pockets, CW for outside profiles

If you don't want to fix this, please at least rename it to CW and CCW, since climb and conventional is different idea.

Also i think conventional should be default! (as most people using bCNC have hobby machines which suffer from deflection). That means that inside profiles and pockets should be CW by default and outside profile should be CCW by default.

I use bCNC on shapeoko and cutting 5mm slot pocket with default settings resulted in 4.2mm slot (because of 0.4mm deflection), so my bolt does not fit to it. When i manualy changed to use real "conventional" milling (by clicking climb!!!), the slot is exactly 5mm wide. This can be confusing for beginners with cheap machines. Sometimes it makes sense to use climb milling to improve surface finish, but i believe the dimensional accuracy is more important in most cases. And people who will need to improve surface finish need to tweak more settings anyway...

title: Tool  change broken?
body: When using the tool change via TLO, the machine first moves the Z-axis down to the tool change location and then to the x/y coordinates (possibly bad?). After successfully probing and setting the TLO, the machine moves back to its x/y start location while in G90 mode and then the Z-axis is moved back up in G90 mode with the z-value after starting. This then crashes the axis into the limit switch, as my machine first moves into the upper left corner with Z raised to the top.

title: Auto-Level Issue
body:
I run my probe at the decently slow rate of 15 mm/min, but my machine allows starts to slope way too deep on one side to the point that it breaks my bits. I have broken more than 20 bits in the last 8 hours trying to figure out what the issue is, does anyone have a clue where I should start?

I clamp down, home the machine, probe the board (15x15 points per inch), go to about center of board, probe z, set zero, hit Z = 0, and then execute the g-code.

title: Metric/Imperial bugs
body:
After using the program for a few days, I have found a couple of issues that are metric "correct" but not if you are using imperial measurements.

First off, the tool path follower lights up correctly, but the tool animation does not (it only moves the metric amount) instead of the imperial amount.

Second, the probe feature, while it does convert the imperial measurements to metric, will not nativly accept imperial measurements.  

The probe grid and the material grid are only in metric and while I can get the probe grid to resize, I have not been able to change the settings for the material grid.

Also, the WorkArea is always negative and about 10 times larger than the Material grid.  Is this by design and/or is there a way of changing the WorkArea to represent the Machine Tool work area?

I don't know if this is GRBL or bCNC, but it ignores an M30 as a program end.  GRBL says it is supported but Universal G-Code sender and bCNC are ignoring this command as a program end.

Lastly, I guess this is confusion on my part, but what is the difference between the program "Pause" and "Stop"?  "Pause" seems to stop the program instantly but will resume when "Pause" is pressed again.  "Stop" seems to no stop but just quit sending G-Code.  Which would be ok, except that usually the buffer still contains about 15 moves.  If you press "Pause" to stop the machine in case of a minor emergency (work piece came out of the vice, tool breaks, tool about to hit the vice, ect.), if you then press "Stop" the stop command is ignored.  If you just press "Stop" the machine seems to continue on its merry way until the buffered commands are executed...  So far, the only solution is to press the soft reset, but this is not ideal as it loses the G92 offsets...

Am I doing this wrong, or is there another way to implement an emergency stop that stops the machine, clears the buffer, and preserves the G92 offsets?

Thanks and even though I am finding bugs, I am REALLY digging your program.  I am running it wirelessly on a RaspberryPi from a browser window and it allows me to run my machine without tying up my design computer.

Please keep up the good work!!!

Bruce

PS I am thinking about making a script that takes a virgin RaspberryPi install and adds all the parts to make it work headless with bCNC.  Linux is not my specialty but I figured I know enough to make a simple script for people who do not know Linux but want a cheap headless CNC controller that is accessible from any browser window.
